gloss: Used to form taxonomic names indicating a lack of some feature that might be expected
ety_desc: From the Ancient Greek ἀ- (a-, “not, without”).

gloss: Used with taxon names to form other taxon names, usually for a morphologically similar taxon differing only in size
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek μέγας (mégas, “great, large, mighty”).

gloss: Very small.; One millionth.
ety_desc: From New Latin micro- (“small”), from Ancient Greek μικρός (mikrós, “small”).

gloss: six
ety_desc: From Latin hexa-, from Ancient Greek ἑξα- (hexa-), from ἕξ (héx, “six”).

gloss: four
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek τετρα- (tetra-).

gloss: Different, dissimilar, other.
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek ἕτερος (héteros).

gloss: new. (Often used to form clade or taxonomic names indicating more recent branching than a morphologically or otherwise similar group.)
examples: Neoceti; Neognathae; Neoptera; Neopterygii; Neornithes
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek νέος (néos, “new, young”).

gloss: used to form genus names, especially from other genus names, indicating smaller size
ety_desc: From Latin -ulus (diminutive suffix).

gloss: Used to create genus names from proper nouns; Used to take the form of certain plural Latin-derived taxonomic names
ety_desc: From Latin -a.

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names and epithets indicating strangeness
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ξένος (xénos, “alien”).

gloss: hyper-
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ὑπέρ (hupér, “over”).

gloss: Used to form adjectives for the species descriptor of a scientific name.
ety_desc: From Latin -i.

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names.
ety_desc: Learned borrowing from Latin -us.

gloss: Head.
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek κεφαλή (kephalḗ, “head”).

gloss: nerves, nerve tissue, or the nervous system.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek νευρο- (neuro-), combining form of νεῦρον (neûron, “sinew, tendon, cord”)

gloss: Synonym of arch-.
ety_desc: Late Latin archi- (“arch-, chief, first”), from Ancient Greek ἀρχι- (arkhi-, “chief, leading”), from ἄρχω (árkhō, “I begin, lead, rule, govern”)

gloss: one of two mirror-image forms of a stereocentre, part of a diastereomer
ety_desc: Abbreviation of Latin sinister (“left”)

gloss: sharp; tip; extremity; peak
ety_desc: From international scientific vocabulary, reflecting a New Latin combining form, from New Latin acro- (“pointed, first, high”) (from Ancient Greek ἄκρος (ákros, “highest, at the extremity”)).

gloss: urine; relating to urine.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek οὖρον (oûron).

gloss: intermediate in size or other characteristic.
examples: Mesocricetus
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek μέσος (mésos, “middle”).

gloss: naked
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek γυμνός (gumnós, “naked”).

gloss: used to form taxonomic names, principally of genera
examples: Chalcomitra; Chalcophaps; Chalcosoma
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek χαλκός (khalkós, “copper”).

gloss: Found in Africa.
ety_desc: New Latin, from stem of Latin Afer (“African”), noun and adjective

gloss: thin, narrow
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek λεπτός (leptós, “thin”).

gloss: Used to form names of divisions or phyla of plants or algae
examples: Anthophyta; Chrysophyta; Euglenophyta; Prymnesiophyta; Pyrrophyta; Rhyniophyta; Trimerophytophyta; Xanthophyta
ety_desc: From New Latin, from Ancient Greek φυτά (phutá), plural of φυτόν (phutón, “plant”), from φύω (phúō, “to bring forth, to produce, to put forth”).

gloss: Used to form names of divisions or phyla of fungi
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek μύκης (múkēs, “mushroom”) + -ota.

gloss: Used to form names of classes of plants
examples: Selaginellopsida; Isoetopsida; Ophioglossopsida
ety_desc: New Latin, from stem of Ancient Greek ὄψις (ópsis, “appearance”)

gloss: Used to form names of classes of algae
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek φῦκος (phûkos, “seaweed, wrack”)

gloss: Used to form names of classes of fungi and some bacteria
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek, a plural form of μύκης (múkēs, “mushroom, fungus, mushroom-shaped objects”)

gloss: Used to form names of subclasses of plants.; Used to form names of families of animals.
ety_desc: Plural of a Latin transliteration of Ancient Greek -ίδης (-ídēs), a patronymic suffix. Known to have been interpreted by some as representing instead the plural of a Latin transliteration of Ancient Greek -ειδής (-eidḗs, adjectival suffix), from εἶδος (eîdos, “appearance, resemblance”). Proposed in 1811 by William Kirby, a British entomologist, to simplify and make uniform the system of Pierre André Latreille which divided insect orders into sections. See more on Wikipedia: Family (biology) § History.

gloss: Used to form names of subclasses of fungi.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek stem of μύκης (múkēs, “mushroom, fungus, mushroom-shaped objects”) + -idae

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of superorders of plants, algae and fungi
examples: Hypnanae; Rhizogonianae
ety_desc: New Latin, from feminine plural of Latin -anus

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of orders.
ety_desc: From Latin -ālis.

gloss: Used to form names of suborders of plants, algae and fungi.
ety_desc: From New Latin -ineae, feminine plural of -ineus, either from Latin -īnus + -eus or rebracketed from words derived from nouns in -in- (e.g. coccineus).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of superfamilies of plants, algae and fungi; Used to form taxonomic names of animals of the rank of order, suborder, or similar; Used to form taxonomic names of animals of the rank of superfamily before the taxonomic code was changed to prohibit such names
ety_desc: From Latin -acea, neutral plural of -aceus: belonging to, the nature of (enlarged from adjective suffix -ax, genitive -acis).

gloss: Used to form the name of taxonomic families of plants, algae, bacteria, and fungi
ety_desc: From the Latin -āceae, the feminine plural of -āceus (“resembling”).

gloss: Used to form the taxonomic names of subfamilies of plants, algae and fungi
ety_desc: New Latin, from Latin feminine plural form of -oideus (“resembling”)

gloss: Used to form names of subfamilies of animals.; Used to form names of subtribes of plants, algae and fungi and viruses.
ety_desc: From Latin -īnae, feminine plural form of -īnus (“-ine”).

gloss: Used to form names of superfamilies of animals. Name may be conserved when the rank is changed, as to a parv-, infra-, or suborder, or an order or higher rank. Previously used to form names of higher rank, eg, class, which are often conserved
ety_desc: New Latin, from Latin neuter plural form of -oideus (“resembling”)

gloss: Used to indicate tribes of animals
ety_desc: New Latin, nominative plural form of Latin -inus

gloss: Used to form higher clades with one main member.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek πᾰν- (păn-).

gloss: Used to form names of taxa according to a prominent anatomical feature.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek -ωτά (-ōtá), neuter plural of -ωτός (-ōtós), verbal adjective from the stem of -όω (-óō, denominal verb suffix). Related to translingual -ote.

gloss: Used to create genera relating to stars; most commonly applied to echinoderms such as starfish and brittle stars.
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek ᾰ̓στήρ (ăstḗr, “star; celestial body”).

gloss: Hidden
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek κρυπτός (kruptós, “hidden, secret”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names corresponding to English vernacular names beginning with true
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek εὖ (eû, “well, good”)

gloss: hypo-
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ὑπο- (hupo-), combining form of ὑπό (hupó, “under”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, especially to form genus names when appended to the name of a person, usually a scientist or a patron.
ety_desc: From Latin -ia and Ancient Greek -ία (-ía), -εια (-eia), which form abstract nouns of feminine gender.

gloss: nonstandard form of da- (“deca-”)
ety_desc: From deca-/deka-. From French SI metric system origins. From Latin decas, from Ancient Greek δέκα (déka, “10”).

gloss: forms taxons from nouns with underlying meaning "having a certain feature"
ety_desc: From the nominative neuter plural of Latin -ātus, -āta, with meaning: "those having, purveyed with (a certain feature)".

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, usually of genera; small-.
examples: -ula at Wikispecies
ety_desc: From Latin -ula. Cognate with Proto-Germanic *-ilaz, whence no longer productive English -le (as in dimple and nozzle), Dutch -el, German -el.

gloss: hand
ety_desc: Ancient Greek χείρ (kheír, “hand”)

gloss: Used to form names for taxa whose members resemble dogs in some way
examples: Cynocephalus; Cynodon; Cynodonichthys; Cynodonmiris; Cynodontia; Cynoglossum; Cynoglossus; Cynoglottis
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek κύων (kúōn, “dog”).

gloss: Branched.; Arm.
ety_desc: New Latin brachio- from Latin bracchium (“limb, branch, arm”)

gloss: Form-changing.; Protein.
examples: Proteoarchaeota; Proteocarpus; Proteocephalus; Proteodes; Proteomyxa; Proteomonas; Proteonematalycus; Proteopharmacis
ety_desc: Derived from New Latin Prōteus, from Ancient Greek Πρωτεύς (Prōteús, “Proteus, a sea god who could change his shape at will”)

gloss: alternative form of μ- as an abbreviation of micro-, mikro-, микро- etc.
ety_desc: Typographical substitution for μ, in environments where either (1) the correct symbol is not available or (2) it is available but the writer feels no need to make any effort to insert it (such as by looking it up in a character map) because they rely on their target reader (an informed one) finding the meaning obvious in context.

gloss: scaly
ety_desc: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek λεπίς, λεπίδος (lepís, lepídos, “scale”).

gloss: rose-colored
ety_desc: Ancient Greek ῥόδον (rhódon, “rose”).

gloss: ant
examples: Myrmecacis; Myrmecaelurus; Myrmecaphodius; Myrmecethelum; Myrmechixenus; Myrmechusa; Myrmechusina; Myrmecia
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek μύρμηκος (múrmēkos, “ant’s”), genitive of μύρμηξ (múrmēx, “ant”)

gloss: A suffix used to form taxonomic names, of genera of bacteria.
examples: Averyella; Buttiauxella; Ewingella; Grimontella; Leminorella; Rahnella; Raoultella; Shewanella
ety_desc: From Latin -ella.

gloss: Ear; ear-like; ear-shaped.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek ὠτ- (ōt-), the stem of οὖς (oûs, “ear”)

gloss: southern
ety_desc: From Latin auster (“south”).

gloss: kerato- (horned; horn-like).
ety_desc: Borrowed from New Latin cerato-.

gloss: ray; radial form
examples: Actinobacteria; Actinopterygii; Actinodura; Actinote; Actinomyces
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek, the stem of ἀκτίς (aktís, “ray”).

gloss: both; near
ety_desc: New Latin amphi- (from Ancient Greek ἀμφί (amphí, “on both sides”))

gloss: Used to form adjectives for the species descriptor of a scientific name.
ety_desc: From Latin -ae.

gloss: Latinizing suffix; suffix for making genera eponymous of a male person
ety_desc: Etymology tree Proto-Indo-European *-yós Old Latin -ios Latin -iusbor. Translingual -ius Borrowed from Latin -ius.

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, usually of genera; long-.
examples: dolicho- at Wikispecies
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek δολιχός (dolikhós)

gloss: Fingered; finger-like
ety_desc: New Latin dactylo- (from Ancient Greek δάκτυλος (dáktulos, “finger”))

gloss: one of two mirror-image forms of a stereocenter, part of a diastereomer; the prefix indicating a codified refigerant
ety_desc: * (stereochemistry): Abbreviation of Latin rectus (“right”)

gloss: hair or hairiness
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek θρίξ (thríx, “hair”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, normally masculine.
ety_desc: From Latin -ītēs, from Ancient Greek -ῑ́της (-ī́tēs).

gloss: tooth; toothed; tooth-like
ety_desc: From New Latin, from Ancient Greek ὀδούς (odoús, “tooth”)

gloss: Forms genus names of lizards.; Forms genus names of dinosaurs, ichthyosaurs, mosasaurs, and other large extinct reptiles.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek σαῦρος (saûros, “lizard, reptile”). The broader use, which has become standard especially for dinosaurs, follows some of the earliest non-avian dinosaur genera to be named, particularly Megalosaurus (literally “giant lizard”).

gloss: With thorns
ety_desc: Borrowed from New Latin, from Ancient Greek ἄκανθος (ákanthos, “thorn plant”), from ἄκανθα (ákantha, “thorn”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, principally orders of animals.
ety_desc: From New Latin, from the Latin plural of -fōrmis (“-shaped”) (i.e., -fōrmēs), from fōrma (“form, contour, figure, shape, appearance, looks”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, often at the level of genus: resemblance
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ὄψις (ópsis, “aspect, appearance”).

gloss: resembling, -oid, -like
ety_desc: Borrowed from Latin -oīdēs (“-like, -oid”).

gloss: Animal having a spine as specified.
examples: Anacanthus; Anisacanthus; Baphicacanthus; Calycacanthus; Caracanthus; Catacanthus; Caulacanthus; Centracanthus
ety_desc: From New Latin [Term?], from Ancient Greek ἄκανθα (ákantha, “thorn, spine”)

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of animals, usually at the level of infraorder or higher
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek μορφή (morphḗ, “shape, appearance”).

gloss: Used to form genus names of fungi
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek μύκης (múkēs, “mushroom, fungus”).

gloss: Smooth.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek λεῖος (leîos, “smooth”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of a rank higher than genus of animals having feet or foot-like parts
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek, plural of πούς (poús, “foot”)

gloss: Used to form genus names of birds
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek ὄρνις (órnis, “bird”)

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of families of viruses
ety_desc: New Latin Virus + -idae

gloss: Having no shield
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek ἄνοπλος (ánoplos, “without shield”)

gloss: Golden
ety_desc: From Latin aureus (“golden”).

gloss: Invisible.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek ἀφανής (aphanḗs, “unseen”)

gloss: gray.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek φαιός (phaiós, “gray”)

gloss: Japanese.; Native to or discovered in Japan.
ety_desc: From English Nippono-, from Japanese 日本(にっぽん) (Nippon, “Japan”).

gloss: wide, broad
examples: Euryabax; Euryades; Euryale; Euryalusa; Euryancale; Euryapteryx; Euryaptus; Euryarchaeota
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek εὐρύς (eurús, “wide”).

gloss: Used to form medical terms and taxonomic names; milk-related.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek stem γάλακτ- (gálakt-) of γάλα (gála, “milk, milky sap, the Milky Way”)

gloss: Used to form medical terms or taxonomic names relating to a papilla in any sense: either a nipple or resembling a nipple
examples: Papillocepheus; Papilloderma; Papillogobius; papilloma; Papilloma; papillomatous; Papillopscus; papillorenal
ety_desc: From Latin papilla (“nipple, breast, pustule, rose bud”).

gloss: Used to form genus names of extinct crocodyliforms or reptiles resembling crocodiles.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek Σοῦχος (Soûkhos, “the crocodile god Sobek”), from Egyptian Demotic sbk (“Sobek”), from Egyptian sbk (“Sobek”).

gloss: Used to form words relating to wings
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek πτερά (pterá), plural of πτερόν (pterón, “wing”)

gloss: Used to form a taxonomic name, usually of a genus, by suffixation to an existing genus name; a diminutive
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek -ίδιον (-ídion, “diminutive”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of subfamilies of viruses
ety_desc: New Latin Virus + -inae

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names or epithets with the meaning of almost or nearly the term to which it is prefixed
ety_desc: Latin paene (“almost”)

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names and epithets for organisms that have a cloak- or mantle-like structure
examples: Chlamydoconcha; Chlamydodera; Chlamydodon; Chlamydophorus; Chlamydosaurus
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek χλαμύς (khlamús, “cloak, mantle”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of genera of viruses
ety_desc: From New Latin vīrus (“virus”, literally “poison”).

gloss: One of the suffixes used to form taxonomic names of supertribes of plants
Used to form taxonomic names and epithets relating to feet or parts resembling feet.
examples: Octopus; octopus for; Platypus; platypus for; Rhizopus; a fungus; Xenopus; a frog
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek πούς (poús, “foot”).

gloss: Relating to or consisting of undifferentiated plant tissue, as algae.; Lacking vascular tissue.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek θαλλός (thallós, “young shoot, twig”) thallus

gloss: Bearing.
ety_desc: New Latin nominative neuter plural of -fer

gloss: Bearing
ety_desc: Latin from nominative feminine plural of -fer (“bearing”)

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names for taxa of organisms differentiated by having a structure resembling a fringe or a notable edge
examples: Fimbriaglomerella; Fimbriaphis; Fimbriapora; Fimbriaria; Fimbriasacculus; Fimbriatella; Fimbriatus; Fimbriceps
ety_desc: From Late Latin fimbria (“fringe, tassel”), from Latin fimbriae (“fibers”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names: comb.
ety_desc: New Latin, from stem of Ancient Greek κτείς (kteís, “comb”)

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, especially of genera of insects with a sucking-type proboscis
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek μυζάω (muzáō, “I suck”))

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, usually of protozoa (protists)
ety_desc: New Latin, from stem of Latin monas (“one”)

gloss: abbreviation of Lalande, abbreviated prefix for stars under Lalande designations
ety_desc: From French Lal. (“Lalande”).

gloss: wheel
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek τροχός (trokhós)

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names from pre-existing names, indicating more recent discovery or identification or more recent evolutionary descent
examples: Caenocara; Caenolestes
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek καινός (kainós, “new”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, usually of genera
examples: Caenolestes; Rhyncholestes
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek λῃστής (lēistḗs, “thief”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, often of genera, by combination with words indicating a type of food for an organism; eater.
examples: Musciphaga
ety_desc: Ancient Greek φάγος (phágos, “eater, glutton”)

gloss: Used to form names of taxa
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek νόθος (nóthos, “bastard”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of genera of squid
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek τευθίς (teuthís, “small squid”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, principally of genera; single.
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek ἑνικός (henikós, “single”)

gloss: Used to form nouns naming organisms that seem to bear something suggesting what is named by a preceding word element such as a prefix
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek -φόρος (-phóros), from φέρω (phérō, “to bear”).

gloss: Identifying a steel grade with a maximum of 1% carbon.
ety_desc: From AISI and SAE standards nomenclature for iron and steel grades for carbon steels with a maximum of 1% carbon content.

gloss: Identifying a chromium steel grade with roughly 1% chromium, and a varying amount of carbon.
ety_desc: From AISI and SAE standards nomenclature for iron and steel grades for chromium steels with roughly 1% chromium.

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of genera of rabbits
examples: genera in Leporidae; Brachylagus; Caprolagus; Bunolagus; Nesolagus; Oryctolagus; Pentalagus; Poelagus
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek λαγώς (lagṓs, “hare”)

gloss: Used to form the name of an oogenus.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ᾠόν (ōión, “egg”) + λίθος (líthos, “stone”).

gloss: resembling
ety_desc: A borrowing of Ancient Greek -ίδης (-ídēs, “-son, son of”).

gloss: Used to form feminine genus names of dinosaurs or lizards.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek σαύρα (saúra, “lizard”), conceived of as the feminine equivalent for -saurus.

gloss: Resembling.
examples: Acanthidops; Arremonops; Chrysops; Loxops; Strigops; Tursiops
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek ὄψ (óps, “eye, face”), influenced by ὄψῐς (ópsĭs, “appearance”).

gloss: body
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek σῶμα (sôma, “body”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of shrimp-like copepods, principally carideans
ety_desc: From Latin caris (“shrimp, marine crab”), from Ancient Greek καρίς (karís)

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names of plants, especially relating to the nature of their leaves
ety_desc: Ancient Greek φύλλον (phúllon, “leaf, plant”)

gloss: resembling, -oid, -like
ety_desc: Borrowed from Latin -odēs (“-like, -oid”), Ancient Greek -ώδης (-ṓdēs, “-like”)

gloss: head
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek κεφᾰλή f (kephălḗ, “head”), with the Latin suffix -us m.

gloss: Used to form names of genera, according to the appearance of their teeth.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ὀδών (odṓn), variant of ὀδούς (odoús), or reanalysis of English -odont.

gloss: proto-; proto-language; used to create the language codes of proto-languages from the language codes of language families.
ety_desc: PIE word *pró Abbreviation of New Latin proto-, from Ancient Greek πρῶτος (prôtos, “first, firstmost”), from Ancient Greek πρό (pró, “before”), from Proto-Hellenic *pró, from Proto-Indo-European *pró, Proto-Indo-European *per-.
ety_lineage: translingue < NL. < grec < grec < grk-pro < ine-pro < ine-pro

gloss: Used to form names of mammalian genera.
examples: -theria; -theriidae
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek θηρίον (thēríon). Compare the subclass Theria.

gloss: Used to form the taxonomic names of kingdoms of viruses
ety_desc: From Virus. The Latin source of this word would not have had a byform in -ae, perhaps it was created in analogy to the eukaryotic kingdom Plantae.

gloss: forms names describing the mouth.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek στόμα (stóma, “mouth”). Related to English -stome, -stomy.

gloss: Bumpy, spiky, rugged, rough, jagged, bumpy, etc.
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek τρᾱχῠ́ς (trākhŭ́s, “spiky, jagged, prickly, bumpy, etc.”).

gloss: fingered
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek δᾰ́κτῠλος (dắktŭlos, “finger”).

gloss: Used to form taxonomic names, usually of genera, for taxa of organisms, usually with feather- or wing-like features
examples: Anarytropteris; Cardiopteris; Caryopteris; Chaetopteris; Chloropteris; Dictyopteris; Gansuapteris; Glenopteris
ety_desc: Borrowed from Ancient Greek πτέρῐς (ptérĭs, “fern”) (see also Pteris), further from Ancient Greek πτερόν (pterón, “feather; wing”).

gloss: Forms names of eukaryotic taxa at the level of superclass and above.
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ζῷα (zōîa, “animals”).

gloss: Used to form the names of genera of plants
ety_desc: From Ancient Greek ἄνθος (ánthos, “flower”)

gloss: ant
ety_desc: New Latin, from Ancient Greek ἴδρις (ídris, “experienced”), alluding to a verse by Hesiod (Works and Days, 778): ὅτε τ'ἴδρις σωρὸν αμᾶται, "while the experienced one gathers a heap", where many philologists, but not all, interpret ἴδρις as a metaphor for "ant."

gloss: Denotes the number seventeen in compound and scientific terms.
ety_desc: From Latin septendecim (“seventeen”), composed of septem (“seven”) + decem (“ten”). Used as a combining form in neoclassical compounds denoting quantities of seventeen.
